label: Letter from Fong Lee Wong to Laura M. Bragg June 10, 1930
description: In this three page handwritten letter, Fong Lee Wong writes about his difficulty finding a room in Washington D.C., he also learns that he only needs one year of residence to complete his Master's degree at Harvard, and that his friend is not someone that he wants to marry. Fong Lee Wong plans to stay in Washington, D.C. until it is time to start Harvard summer school.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
une 10, 1930

Dear Miss Bragg:

	If I have ever had since the death of my mother a somewhat pathetic feeling of a boy when he leaves his sweet home, it was on last Sunday afternoon. I can not tell you how it is for I want words to describe it. Well what I can say now is that I always bear your motherly picture in my hear wherever I go.

	I promised to write to you yesterday, but I was too tired because I did not sleep all the night on the train. The actual cause which gave me no time to write to you was that I had to find a room--a very hard task--for myself as I could not and can not stay in our Mission. I spent all yesterday afternoon and forenoon to hunt for a room, but I met a fruitless [2] result. I cold not continue this fruitless work last night because I suppered with Mr. Mei and two Chinese generals who came to the United States only a week ago after their political life had been dead for quite a long while. There were greatly amazed by the prosperouls outlook of the United States and stayed in our Mission until half past eleven when I became too tired and could talk to them no longer.

	Harvard University gave me a very favorable answer to my application, re--quiring me only one year's residence to finish my Master degree. But I see I must work hard.

	Regarding my friend, she has definitely turned out a girl I do not want to marry. This is all that I can say of here. I must mind my own future and my own work now. I am still tired and must stop.

	Yours affectionately, 

	Fong Lee
[3]
[P.S.] This whole morning was also spent in finding a room. Just when I began to think of going to Cambridge, Mass. I succeeded in getting a room This was at twelve o'clock. Now I have all my things moved to this room and plan to stay until it is the time for me to to to Harvard Summer School. F.L.

[From:] F.L. Wong
2032 I Street, N.W.
Washington, D.C.

[Address:] Miss Laura M. Bragg
38 Chalmers Street
Charleston, S.c.
